entry.title: About Me
entry.summary: This section provides a summarize of my research interests.
entry.content:
Research interest

My research interests include, but are not limited to Variability Modeling, Software Product Lines, Feature Models, software testing, Binary Decision Diagrams, and Bibliometric Techniques.

Publications

Speeding up Derivative Configuration from Product Platforms

Heradio, R.; Fernandez-Amoros, D.; Perez-Morago, H.; Adan, A

Journal Paper Entropy June 2014, Volume 17, Pages 3329-3356
Impact factor (Journal Citation Reports) | 2nd Quartile


Augmenting Measure Sensitivity to Detect Essential, Dispensable and Highly Incompatible Features in Mass Customization

Heradio, R.; Perez-Morago, H.; Alferez, M.; Fernandez-Amoros, D.; Alferez G.

Journal Paper European Journal of Operational Research, August 2015, 248(3):1066-1077
Impact factor 2.679 (Journal Citation Reports) | 1st Quartile


A Bibliometric Analysis of 20 Years of Research on Software Product Lines

Heradio, R.; Perez-Morago, H.; Fernandez-Amoros, D.; Cabrerizo, Francisco Javier; Herrera-Viedma, Enrique

Journal Paper Information and Software Technology, 72, April 2016
Impact factor 1.569 (Journal Citation Reports) | 2nd Quartile


Efficient Identification of Core and Dead Features in Variability Models

Hector Perez-Morago, Ruben Heradio, David Fernandez-Amoros, Roberto Bean and Jose Antonio Cerrada

Journal Paper IEEE Access. Nov 2015.
Impact factor 1.249 (Journal Citation Reports) | 1st Quartile


Science Mapping Analysis of the Literature on Software Product Lines.

Heradio, R.; Perez-Morago, H.; Fernandez-Amoros, D.; Cabrerizo, Francisco Javier; Herrera-Viedma, Enrique

Conference Paper The 14th International Conference on Intelligent Software Methodologies, Tools and Techniques Monumental Complex of St. Chiara, Naples, Italy September 15-17, 2015


Binary Decision Diagram Algorithms to Perform Hard Analysis Operations on Variability Models.

Heradio, R.; Perez-Morago, H.; Fernandez-Amoros, D.; Bean, Roberto; Cabrerizo, Francisco Javier; Cerrada, Carlos; Herrera-Viedma, Enrique Conference Paper The 15th International Conference on Intelligent Software Methodologies, Tools and Techniques. Larnaca, Cyprus, 12-14, 2016

Conference Paper The 14th International Conference on Intelligent Software Methodologies, Tools and Techniques. Larnaca, Cyprus, 12-14, 2016


Phd dissertation

BDD Algorithms to Perform Hard Analysis Operations on Variability Models.

Héctor José Pérez Morago Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia (España). Escuela Internacional de Doctorado. Programa de Doctorado en Ingeniería de Sistemas y Control

Abstract To compete in the global marketplace, manufacturers try to differentiate their products by focusing on individual customer needs. Fulfilling this goal requires companies to shift from mass production to mass customization. In the context of software development, software product line engineering has emerged as a cost-effective approach to developing families of similar products by supporting high levels of mass customization. Variability models are often used to specify the common and variable features of the products in one such family. Moreover, they model the inter-feature constraints which must be satisfied to guarantee the validity of the derived products. Despite the benefits of variability models, constructing and maintaining them can be a laborious task, especially in product lines with a large number of features and constraints. As a consequence, the study of automated techniques to reason on variability models has become an important research topic for the product line community.

Full version
